description: This is no ordinary bookstore, thanks to its selection of rare and unusual volumes (published pre-1980) and its one-of-a-kind Bibliomat, the world's first book vending machine.

reviews.title: Unusual Books!
text: Quirky and unusual books fill the shelves here. Found many treasures. But we really enjoyed using the Bible-Matic which is a vending machine where you place a token in and get a mystery book. It's so fun. One of the highlights of Toronto! And great area for brunch!

reviews.title: Cool book shop
text: A really quirky cool little book shop. Lots of interesting old and rare books. The bibliomat at the back of the store is definitely worth a go. Put your token in and wait while the machine whirs and turns and delivers you a random old book. Owner is friendly and an interesting guy. It was worth the 50 min walk across town on our recent visit to Toronto.

reviews.title: Cool Place!
text: It's a vintage bookstore. Some really interesting titles. But the highlight is the Bibliomat in the back; purchase a $5 token, insert it, and get a random book! The people just after us got a Book of Mormon. (LOL!!) Like those aren't free at every Marriott hotel. Fun place; especially for bookworms.

reviews.title: Lovely
text: This is such a lovely and unique used book shop! You’ll find a vast selection of vintage treasures in there! We saw some books from the 1800’s and to me, that is more than worth the visit! The biblio-matic is really fun as well. It’s $3 per person, you can only do it once (a day, I believe) and you get a randomized book. If you love books, I highly recommend stopping by here and picking something up!

reviews.title: One of a kind
text: When planning our trip to Toronto I stumbled across the Monkey's Paw and it's Biblio-Matic vending machine.  I know this was a must-stop place for me since I am a bibliophile and could spend hours in libraries and book stores.  The new location was not too far from our hotel and was easy to find.  The store did not disappoint, it is small but well-appointed with lots of shelves with books as well as some beautiful plates from books that were unsalvageable.  I spent less time than I would have perusing the books because my husband was with me and it's not really his thing (although he did find a book he liked), but despite not taking as long I did find a couple of great books myself and had a chance to talk to the owner for a bit.  Of course, we had to buy a token to try the Biblio-Matic, the book it chose for us was Diseases of Fish, which was perfect, my husband loves fishing and he was thrilled at the selection.  If you enjoy books this is a stop that should be at the top of the list if you visit Toronto.

reviews.title: A Pilgrimage
text: We were only staying in Toronto for 4 days but knew before we left Ireland that we had to visit here. A family member had sent us a newspaper article about the store.
The store is very well maintained and the lady manning the desk when we arrived was very friendly and welcoming but not at all intrusive.
We looked around the store for nearly an hour. We asked for one or two books and the lady checked her computer and the shelves but couldn't find them.

The we went to the Bibliomat we got a token for $2 and put the token in the machine. There was great anticipation as to which book we'd get and sure enough both books that came out were ones we'd never have chosen but we've read with interest. We also picked up one or two books that we liked for very reasonable prices.
It's a bit of a trek from downtown Toronto but if you are into second hand book shops you cannot skip this one.

reviews.title: Great Book Store!
text: My husband and I absolutely loved this place! We spent over an hour browsing through the books and bought some really unique books as gifts for our friends and family.
I was fascinated with the etiquette and health books from the early twentieth century.
If you are a bibliophile, I would highly recommend this shop!

reviews.title: Not A Particularly Good Used Book Store
text: The biblio-o-mat is a very cute idea, and a great way for the store to get publicity. But in reality the books that come out are the sorts of things you see in boxes outside garage sales under a sign that reads "Free"

The rest of the selection is eclectic and brutally overpriced. An example - a paperback edition of Dylan Thomas' story collection (in average shape) "Adventures in the Skin Trade" is $18. Apparently it was a first edition of the American mass market paperback printing from 1956.
I bought the exact same book - same printing, same shape - a number of years ago at another (sadly defunct) used book store in Toronto for $2.50. Other examples abound...

But the guy who worked there was pleasant enough. Just don't make this store or its machine - which the clerk had to stand behind to make sure it worked on the day we visited - a destination in itself. Not much to browse through.

reviews.title: Experience A Second Helping of Second-Hand & Unusual Books
text: Hosting the the world's first book vending machine (Bilio-Mat), this quaint bookstore is nothing but a paradise. For 3 dollars, you get a book- any as it is a surprise for you to own (I got a A Centaur Looks Back: Leckie).

Treasuring second-hand books, the backdrop score of Turkish orchestra rings in for a perfect afternoon idling. Steven was helpful and even assisted me with navigation to Yorkdale Mall. They have this neo-classical themed tiny chandeliers which makes you feel at home.
- SID

reviews.title: Biblio-Mat!
text: The Monkey’s Paw bookstore is, simply put, fantastic. It is both extraordinary and imaginative. When you walk through these doors, you immediately feel as if you’ve been whisked off into some Kafkaesque dream – highly appropriate given the name of this unique shop. You won’t find your Danielle Steeles, your Dan Browns, your Stephen Kings or even your Margaret Atwoods here. Oh no! That’s because the Monkey’s Paw doesn’t sell traditional literature; in fact, the owner won’t even buy anything published before 1980. The focus here, in keeping with the “Monkey’s Paw” theme, is on the uncommon, the bizarre and the esoteric.

At the back of the shop, you will undoubtedly spy the world’s first – and so far only – Biblio-Mat. The Biblio-Mat is a homemade random automatic book dispenser that will release a unique tome for a mere $2. It is probably the biggest draw, having been profiled in major articles and newspapers like the CBC, BBC, National Post and the Wall Street Journal. In fact, it was through a recent article on Global that my partner and I first became aware of the Monkey’s Paw. Our intention was just to visit, utilize the Biblio-Mat, quickly browse the book selection and then leave; however, we got pulled in and ended up spending over $100 on some unique and old books over and above what we got from the Biblio-Mat.
If you’re in the market for something strange and unusual, then forget Indigo and come to the Monkey’s Paw. Who knows, you just might “find the book you didn’t know you were looking for!”

reviews.title: Amazing bookstore!
text: I love this store. Most of the books are from the mid 20th century and the idea of the book vending machine is genius. I would like to visit often and have 70% of the books in the store. The books are unique and interesting. You can definitely tell that the books were carefully considered to be included to the shop. I love it here!

reviews.title: Leave your Kindle at the door.......
text: First thing to advise: The Monkeys Paw has moved and is now at:
1267 Bloor St West, Toronto
Phone number is the same.

This store is a fantastic , eclectic book shop, with a magnificent mix of hardbacks and paperbacks from different eras , factual, fictional, fantastic! I didn't plan on buying anything but found a fantastic set of the Gormenghast trilogy by Mervyn Peake. I think it's hard to walk out without something, and if you can't decide, then you can always use the Bibliomat , which chooses a book for you at random. The owner said that this is so popular he can have trouble keeping it stocked!
Definitely worth a visit.

reviews.title: Leave Your Coffee At The Door
text: It is time for another book store review because I can't help myself. I have a gravitational pull to book stores that kicks in almost as quickly as I get off the plane.

When heading over to The Monkey's Paw, I was in full tourist mode, which included having my camera at-the-ready. Stephen Fowler, the owner of The Monkey's Paw, looked at me a little disapprovingly when I took the above picture outside of the shop.

So, I was slightly embarrassed when I cautiously walked in, but then he asked me to keep the coffee I as clutching at the front of the store. TWO book store violations in just a few minutes. I was not in top form. In my nicest and meekest voice possible, I said "sure" and tried not to break any more rules. I truly am in the elite class of book-store-frequenters; these were rookie moves.

Just to be clear, he wasn't mean or aggressive. His look to me outside and his desire to keep beverages at the front was to protect the goodies inside his shop that were well selected and curated. He seemed like a thoughtful person. In his conversations with customers, I heard him offer to email recommended books to customers while giving a thorough origin story to The Biblio-Mat.

From the website: The Biblio-Mat is a coin-operated vending machine that dispenses randomly-selected old books. It is the first device of its kind, allowing curious bibliophiles to sample the excitement and mystery of antiquarian-book hunting for the coast of a single $2 coin. The Biblio-Mat was designed and constructed for the Monkey's Paw by animator Craig Small.

The Biblio-Mat is ridiculously awesome. Customers were fascinated by it AND were actively using it. Seeing what each customer was getting (the topics were pretty wide-ranging) was really fun. For a place that looks a little haunted, it has some levity as well.

Speaking of haunted, The Monkey's Paw's interior was designed to reference the W.W. Jacobs (horror) short story with the same name. Do you remember that story from your (insert the name of a Liberal Arts College) Short Story Class? Just me?
Ugh, it was so awful. Here is my amazing summary:

There was this guy who came back from a trip to India with a monkey's paw (because he was in the service, possibly- bear with me, I am just getting warmed up here). He tells this small family (a husband, wife and their grown son) the story of the monkey's paw, which was that the paw has the ability to grant three wishes, but the last person who made three wishes used their third wish to ask for death. Big stuff. The guy who came from India tried to destroy the monkey's paw dramatically while telling the story, but the husband he was telling the story to saved it and used it to wish for money. Not a ton of money, just enough to pay off his house. Then, (this is the first gross part) the son is killed by machinery in his company. Coincidentally (actually the opposite of coincidentally- this is all because of THE PAW), his family is compensated the exact amount of money his father asked the monkey's paw for to pay off their house. Ewwwww. THEN, the wife uses the monkey's paw to revive her son (although he has been dead AWHILE now) and there is a knock on the door. The husband (who made the first terrible wish and the second to bring back his dead son because his wife asked him to) makes a third wish for his son to go away before the wife can answer the door. So messed up. Seriously, stop messing with fate.
Man, I should write book reports professionally and only about stories I haven't read in 15 years. Solid career choice.

ANYWAY, is it a place where you could spend hours walking around? Probably not. It is a relatively small store and, where the texts are interesting, the store is a little more resistant to that type of lolly-gagging than most other books stores I have been in. But here (following The Monkey's Paw theme), your wishes are books that you can straight pay for (using "loonies" and "toonies"- Canadian money is hilarious) instead of having to lose a loved one. Just saying.
In closing, a series of questions and answers that really could be written as statements, but aren't because it is more fun and theatrical to write this way:
Are there medical drawings on the wall? Yes.
Is everything arranged by subject? Yes. (And some of them are... interesting.)
Is there a stuffed crow on a typewriter? Yes.
Did I buy a copy of a Calvino and a Neruda? Duh, of course.
Swing on by, just be cool about your camera and keep your coffee at the door.
